O índice de acidez deve ser inferior a 2,0 mg KOH/g para que a transesterificação seja eficiente (ALBUQUERQUE, 2006) . Conforme citado anterior mente, o máximo de teor de água permitido é de 2 %(m/m) para o cenário avaliado. Portanto os resultados obtidos de umidade e índice de acidez foram aceitáveis , ressaltando -se que a amostra 6 apresentou índice de acidez no limite máximo pré -estabele cido pel a literatura.

Seguindo o procedimento utilizado para a reação de transesterificação alcalina, fixando nesta etapa a quantidade do catalisador NaOH a 1 % da massa total de óleo , foram produzidas bateladas de biodiesel bruto. Após decantação da glicerina, lav agem com água quente e secagem, o biodiesel purificado foi caracterizado (T ABELA 16):

40% de óleo de fritura tratado (% em massa ) Parâmetros Amostras Tempo reacional (min) 60 60 60 60 60 60 Cor Normal Normal Normal Normal Normal Normal Fonte: Autor, 2020 Todas as amostras foram reprovadas , segundo a RNAP 45/2014 , para o teste de estabilidade oxidativa, indicando a necessidade de utilização de agentes antioxidantes. A reprovação no teste e stá relacionada co m o perfil lipídico do s óleos vegetais, predominantemente , insaturado s (FIGURAS 21 e 22 ). O teor de água em todas as amostras se apresent ou acima d o limite estabelecido de 200 mg/kg . Mesmo após aquecimento e adição de adsorvente foi obtido um teor de água final acima da especificação . Não foi possível realizar o aquecimento a pressão atmosférica por um tempo prolongado para evitar a degradação da s amostras. No entanto, tal fato pode ser facilmente contornável nas usinas, utilizando -se vácuo n a etapa de seca gem.

Os demais resultados obtidos para as amostras 1, 2 e 3 (0 %, 10 % e 20 % de óleo usado na composição da mistura, respectivamente) apresentaram -se dentro de faixa de especificaç ão do biodiesel . A amostra 4 (25 % de óleo usado na mistura) indicou result ados no limi te da especificação para os demais parâmetros, en quanto os resultados d as amostras 5 e 6 (30 % e 40 % de óleo de fritura, respectivamente) não atenderam à especificação.

A medida que o percentual de óleo de fritura aumenta na mistura, o índice de acidez aumenta e o teor de éster diminui para o produto final gerado . O aumento da umidade na matéria -prima pode ocasionar a geração de ácidos graxos livres, provocando reações indesejáveis de saponificação e, consequentemente, redução do rendimento da reação.

Outras misturas foram preparadas , sendo variada a quantidade do catalisador utilizado na reação. A TABELA 17 indica o índice de acidez, umidade e composição mássica das misturas preparadas para avaliação dos efeitos da quantidade do catalisador nas reações.

Ressalta -se que as amostra s 4, 7 e 10 são alíquota s de uma mesma amostra matriz contendo 25% de OCU pesada previamente . As análises de índice de acidez e teor de umidade foram realiza das nesta matriz e replicadas para as 3 amostras , que foram pesadas exatamente com a mesma massa (90,09 g) , para que avaliações posteriores fossem realizadas no maior grau de precisão possível. O mesmo ocorre u para as sequências de amostras 5, 8 e 11 e 6, 9 e 12.

Misturas contendo 25 % (amostras 7 e 10) , 30 % (amostras 8 e 11) e 40 % (amostras 9 e 12) de óleo de cozinha foram reagidas com metanol na presença de NaOH a 1,2 % e 1,5 % da massa total de óleo . As misturas partiram da composição mássica de 25 % de óleo usado, tendo em vista que os resultados para essa composição nos primeiros testes foram considerados no limi te da especificação para todos os parâmetros do biodiesel. Já o aumento de 1,20 % para 1,5 %, trouxe um rendimento ligeiramente m enor (amostras O aumento de 1 % para 1,20 % de NaOH em reações com misturas com 30 % de óleo de fritura, t ambém foi satisfatório quanto ao teor de éster e ao índice de acidez . No aumento de 1,20 % para 1,5 % de NaOH no meio reacional, mais uma vez, houve redução no rendimento da rea ção (amostras 8 e 11).

O comportamento com o incremento da quantidade de catalisador na reação é o mesmo para misturas com 40 % de óleo de fritura. Em um primeiro momento, o aumento é benéfico para a reação, trazendo um maior rendimento d e produto final e menor índice de acidez (amostras 6 e 9), porém depois com o incremento ocorre queda do percentual de éster gerado (amostras 9 e 12) . Mesmo com o aumento de catalisador no meio rea cional para as amostras 9 e 12, o teor de éster no produto final produzido nã o atende às especificações da RNAP 45/2014. O aumento do catalisador no meio pode nos direcionar a maiores rendimentos ou, até mesmo, a mecanismos de reações para a formação de outros produtos, reduzindo a quantidade do produto final desejado. Reações de s aponificação podem ter ocorrido no aumento de 1,20 % para 1,5 % de NaOH nas reações.
4.3 Resultados de Estabilidade com a Utilizaç ão de Agentes Antioxidantes

Os agentes antioxidantes utilizados n esse estudo foram testados em diferentes conc entrações e adicionados ao biodiesel obtido a partir da mistura mássica de 80 % de óleo refinado com 20% de óleo usado , conforme descrito no item 3.3.4 . Após a realização do teste de estabilidade oxidativa, o s resultados da

O TBHQ indicou resultados satisfatórios nas concentrações de 757 mg/kg e 884 mg/kg . Já o Kerobit 3627 apresentou resultados satisfatórios nas três concentrações pre paradas para o estudo . Entretanto, o aumento na estabilidade das amostras aditivadas com BHT e Kerobit TP2 6 nas concentrações estudadas , não foi suficiente para super ar o limite estabelecido na especificação de q ualidade do biodiesel, que foi alterado em 2019 para 12 h.

O antioxidante de base amina (Kerobit 3627) teve melhor desempenho quando comparado a os antioxidantes do tipo fenólico (Kerobit TP26, BHT e TBHQ). O TBHQ teve maior eficiência quando comparado ao BHT e Kerobit TP26, indicando que a interaçã o entre tal aditivo e os radicais livres formados foi mais estável, conferindo um tempo de resistência à oxidação maior para o óleo. O óleo de fritura presente na matéria -prima do biodiesel contribui para que uma maior quantidade de antioxidante seja adic ionada a fim de elevar a estabilidade oxidativa. A presença de ácidos g raxos livres em maior teor e a redução da estabilidade à oxidação pelo tempo de fritura, são fatores negativos para a qualidade do biodiesel final quanto ao aspecto avaliado.
4.4 Compa ração de Custos de Produç ão: Óleo Refinado vs Óleo Refinado /OCU

Para a comparação dos custos de produção, foi utilizado um modelo em escala semi -industrial com capacidade de produção de 1000 L/dia, processando 200 L de óleo por batelada. A planta usada c omo referência pertence à empresa Biotechnos e processa óleo vegetal refina do e/ou OCU por meio de reação de transesterificação alcalina para a produção de biodiesel. Não há etapa de lavagem do biodiesel bruto nesse processo, fato que reduz ainda mais os c ustos. A purificação do biodiesel é realizada por filtros de adsorção capazes de remover impurezas , tais como , metanol não reagido, traço s do catalisador e sabão. A seguir , é apresentado o esquema da usina que será usada como referência para o estud o (FIGU RA 23)
mesa de filtração, (C) tanque de aquecimento, (D ) reator de transesterificação, (E) destilador flash, (F) decantadores e (G) filtros de ads orção.
Fonte: DANTAS , 2016

No recebimento de óleo residual de cozinha, é realizada uma filtragem com aquecimento por duas resistências de 4000 W para remover materiais particulados. O aquecimento ocorre para reduzir a viscosidade do óleo, facilitando a filtração, sendo realizado na temperatura entre 60 °C e 65 °C. Uma bomba centrífuga é parte integrante do conjunto (dados fornecidos pelo fabricante). Resíduos orgânicos eliminados nessa etapa podem ser reaproveitados para a produção de compostagem. Após a filtração, o óleo é enviando para bombonas decantadoras para separação de água contida no meio.
A matéria -prima é enviada para um tanque de aquecimento, sendo mantida na faixa de 60 °C para possibilitar maior eficiência na reação de transesterificação alcalina.
No vaso misturador, metanol é misturado com hidróxido de sódio e aquecido até a temperatura de interesse. A matéria -prima e o alcóxido gerado são bombeados para o reator.

O reator de aço inoxidável possui um sistema de agitação. No equipamento ocorre a reação de transesterificação alca lina durante um período de 45 min . O biodiesel e a glicerina gerados na reação são direcionados para um destilador flash com intuito de recuperar o metanol em excesso. O metanol evaporado é condensado em um resfriador e por gravidade é armazenado em um tanque.

A mistura de biodiesel e glicerina é então bombeada para decantadores para promover a separação entre os produtos. Após a decantação ocorrer, a glicerina é bombeada para tanques de armazenamento e o biodiesel é bo mbeado para a etapa de purificação.

Na etapa de purificação, o biodiesel é tratado em filtros (colunas) de adsorção de leito fixo com resina de troca iônica para remoção de impurezas. Ao final, o produto é estocado em um tanque de armazenamento.

Serão cons iderados dois cenários para o estudo, cenário “A” utilizando óleo de soja refinado como carga de entrada e cenário “B” utilizando a mistura de 80 % e 20 % de óleo de soja e OCU , respectivamente. A metodologia de custos de produção agrícola da CONAB (2010) foi utilizada como referência para a análise. O custo de produção foi definido como a soma dos custos variáveis e fixos da usina de produção.

Os resultados obtidos nos experimentos foram usados para os cálculos de rendimentos e quantidades de produtos e r eagentes na unidade, servindo como base para elaboração dos custos de produção da usina proposta. Algumas informações foram fornecidas pelo fabricante da usina e outras foram obtidas em pesquisas de trabalhos sobre a usina referência.
Utilizando os dados d e densidade da TABELA 20, é possível realizar conversões para que uma base mássica de cálculo seja construída possibilitando análises pertinentes ao estudo.

CAPITULO 05. CONCLUS ÕES

Testes preliminares em laboratório indicaram a possibilidade de produção de biodiesel especificado a partir d a mistura de óleo de soja refinado com óleo de fritura usado em proporções mássicas de 80 % e 20 %, respectivamente, sem que haja a necessidad e de um tratamento para reduzir a acidez do óleo de fritura. O aumento do catalisador de 1 % pa ra 1,20 % sobre a massa total de óleo foi benéfico para a s reações, permitindo a utilização de um percentual maior de óleo de fritura nas misturas , produzindo b iodiesel dentro dos parâmetros especificados. Os resultados das amostras com o aumento do catalisador para 1,5 % não foram satisfatórios , apresenta ram índice de acidez e teor d e ésteres fora de especificação, indicando a ocorrência de reações paralelas no meio.
Para todas as amostras caracterizadas houve reprovação no teste de estabilidade oxidativa, conforme esperado devido ao alto grau de insaturações presentes n as matérias -primas avaliadas .

Os testes de estabilidade oxidativa realizados na mistura 80:20 (óleo refinado:OCU ) com o uso dos antioxidantes avaliados (TBHQ, BHT, Kerobit TP26 e Kerobit 3627 ), em 3 concentrações diferentes, mostraram que t odos os resultados com o Kerobit 3627 foram satisfatórios, sendo o antioxidante de maior performance nos test es. Os result ados para o TBHQ nas concentrações de 757 mg/kg e 884 mg/kg atenderam aos limites estabelecidos . Os demais antioxidantes produziram resultados fora de especificação nas concentrações analisadas no trabalho. A comparação dos custos de produção entre o cenário “A” (utilização de óleo de soja refinado como matéria -prima) e o cenário “B” (utilizaçã o de mistura contendo 20 % de OCU ) apresentou uma redução de até 7 % para o cenário “B”, em uma usina processando 1 .000 L/dia de óleo. O custo com o óle o de soja representou mais de 83 % do custo de produção para o cenário “A”, justificando a necessidade de busca por matérias -primas al ternativas de menor custo de mercado. Fantinel (2016) e Dantas (2016), relatam dificuldades em seus trabalhos para produzir por transesterificação biodiesel dentro das faixas de especificação estabelecidas pela ANP, quando a matéria -prima consumida no processo é composta somente de OCU . A mistura de OCU com o ó leo vegetal refinado seria uma das alternativa s para eliminar esse problema , pro porcionando produção de biodiesel com a qualidade necessária para uso , sem necessidade de modificação nas tecnologias existentes nas usinas.

O uso de óleo fritura em reações para a produção biodiesel, além de reduzir os custos de produção, col abora par a a reutilização de um resíduo e, consequentemente , minimiza os impactos ambientais em nosso planeta. Aspectos relacionados à disponibilidade por região e ao preço atual muito elevado do óleo refinado, indicam a utilização do OCU como uma boa alte rnativa para a geração de biodiesel.
APÊNDICE. ARTIGO EM INGLÊS
REUSE OF USED COOKING OIL IN THE PRODUCTION OF BIODIESEL FROM THEIR PROCESSING IN MIXTURE WITH REFINED OILS AND PERFORMANCE OF STABILITY TESTS.
FELIPE LEAL SIMÕESa slfuerj@yahoo.com.br

aFederal University of Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), Graduate program in Engineering of Chemical and Biochemical processes (EQ/EPQB), Horácio Macedo Avenue 2030, Centro de Tecnologia, block E, University City, Ilha do Fundão, Rio de Janeiro, RJ , Brazil
Abstract

The biofuels market grows gradually in the world as more stringent laws and treaties are implemented to control the emission of particulate materials and gases that generate the greenhouse effect (GHG), notably CO2 and NOx. In addition to regulatory issues, aspects related to the use of renewable raw materials with a focus on sustainability and cost reduction encourage the development of new technologies and routes for the production of biofuels. In this context, several products generat ed from biomass gain prominence, among them biodiesel. In order to produce biodiesel from cheaper raw materials and to reduce the environmental impact owing to the inadequate disposal of residual oils and fats, one of the objectives of this work was to pre pare mixtures in different mass compositions between samples of refined soybean oil and used cooking oil (UCO) previously treated aiming to generate biodiesel in alkaline transesterification reaction from these mixtures. The pre -treatment of UCO was based on waste filtering and removal of free water stages, with no treatment to reduce acidity. At the end of the process, analyzes of acidity index and water content were performed, generating the results of 6.84 mg KOH/g and 838.5 mg/kg, respectively. The vari ous oil mixtures were reacted with methanol in the presence of 1% NaOH as catalyst, and samples of biodiesel were produced for quality assessment in accordance with the ANP (National Petroleum Agency) resolution No. 45/2014. Samples containing up to 20% UC O showed satisfactory results. For compositions in which the biodiesel generated was at the limit or out of specification, other reactions were carried out by varying the amount of catalyst for evaluating the results. The reactions occurred with 1.2 and 1. 5% of the alkaline catalyst. All results of oxidative stability were outside the specification limits, which indicated the need to use antioxidants. Given the scenario, there was the motivation to conduct tests with antioxidants offered on the market. Samp les with different concentrations of TBHQ, BHT, Kerobit TP 26 and Kerobit 3627 in biodiesel were prepared and tested by the Rancimat method to characterize their oxidation stability. The Kerobit 3627 product showed higher performance in the tested concentr ations.
Keywords: Biodiesel. Used Cooking Oil (UCO). Alkaline Transesterification. Oxidative stability.
1. Introduction

The biofuels market grows gradually in the world as more stringent laws and treaties are implemented to control the emission of parti culate materials and gases that generate the greenhouse effect (GHG), notably CO2 and NOx.

The production of biofuels is also an alternative to reduce dependence on fossil fuels. A high degree of importance must also be attributed to the development of new technological routes based on biomass, which introduces a new concept of biorefinery, increasing productivity efficiency and generating materials that are not currently widely available on the market. Examples are glycerol, a byproduct of biodiesel produc tion, which can be converted into solvents, acrylic acid or lactic acid. Programs encouraging the production and use of biofuels have been implemented in several countries in recent decades, such as ethanol in Brazil and the United States, and biodiesel, w hose industrial production has been leveraged in the last decade in various regions of the planet. It is noteworthy that Brazil is a pioneer in Latin America regarding the use of biofuels. Decree -law No. 737 of 1938 [1] and, subsequently, Law No. 8723 of 1 993 [2] deal with the mandatory use of ethanol mixed with gasoline.

Still addressing the Brazilian context, as it is a country very dependent on road transport, there is a relatively large consumption of diesel and, consequently, biodiesel. With the implem entation of the federal law 11097/2005 [3], which introduced biodiesel into the Brazilian market, consecutive increases in the mixture of biodiesel with diesel were determined and it is currently at 12 % (B12). Fig. 1 shows the evolution of biodiesel produ ction in Brazil. In 2019, Brazilian production was approximately 5.9 million cubic meters [4].
Fig. 1. Biodiesel production in Brazil (m3). Source: ANP - Statistical Yearbook, 2020.

From the data presented, it is possible to state that the production o f biodiesel in a few years will move to a level of greater relevance and, therefore, research aimed at the diversification of raw materials, development of new technological routes, as well as the improvement of existing ones, will be necessary to make the business even more viable.

Biodiesel can be produced from oils and fats of vegetable or animal origin. When using vegetable oils and fats of agricultural origin, direct competition with food production occurs in many cases, mainly in small countries.

Braz il does not yet suffer from this problem, however the countries of the European Union already face this limitation, which motivated the recent approval of new rules to be followed with biofuels through the renewable energy directive of 2009 [5] and its rev ision in 2015 [6], where the following aspects must be fulfilled:

● A quota of 20% of all energy produced in the country must be from a renewable source and 10% of that energy from renewable sources must be used in transport. Of the total renewable energy to be used in the transport sector, only 7% can be produced from food crops. ● To be considered sustainable, biofuels must achieve greenhouse gas savings of at least 35% compared to fossil fuels. This savings requirement rose to 50% in 2017. In 2018, it rose t o 60%, but only for new production plants. All life cycle emissions are taken into account when calculating greenhouse gas savings. This includes emissions from cultivation, processing and transportation.
● The raw materials used in the production of biofuel s cannot be grown in areas of transformed land, with high carbon stocks, such as wetlands or forests.
● Biofuels cannot be produced from raw materials grown on land with high biodiversity, such as primary forests or highly biodiverse meadows.

Prospecting fo r the future by citing the countries of the European Union as an example, but not in a scenario so distant from the Brazilian reality, it comes as a sound option the production of biodiesel using as raw material residues from slaughterhouses, tanneries or waste oils and fats from frying in cafeterias, restaurants, bars and homes.

The use of these oils and fats from fried foods in products such as soap and putty would not be feasible as they would have a low added value. Its use in animal feed, in addition t o also having a low added value, once it presents a high oxidation rate with formation of peroxides, would make its use dangerous, causing problems for people who consume animals fed with this feed [7]. When using oils and fats from fried foods for the pro duction of biodiesel, in addition to the reuse of a byproduct, avoiding the disposal of these residues in the environment, there would also be the production of a product with high added value, with several applications on the national and international sc ene.

However, most plants produce biodiesel using transesterification technology, which requires refined raw materials with low moisture content and free fatty acids. In order for these plants to be able to process the used frying oils without having to i ncur additional expenses due to the implementation of new technologies, it is necessary to evaluate some alternatives. In this context, there was the motivation to carry out this work, which aims to reuse used cooking oil (UCO) in the production of biodies el from its processing in mixture with refined oils. The specified biodiesel, produced from the mixture of refined oil with the largest possible amount of UCO, will be used to evaluate the antioxidant potential of 5 additives.
1.1. Raw material

Biodie sel can be produced basically from oils and fats of vegetable and animal origin and also from residual oils and fats. It is also studied, on an experimental scale, the production of biodiesel from microalgae, having as main stages the production and harves t of biomass (microalgae) and the extraction and conversion of oil into biodiesel [7].

All of these raw materials have triglycerides in their structure, which are fatty acids esterified with glycerin. Vegetable oils are the most consumed in the world for t he production of biodiesel, especially rapeseed (canola), soybean and palm oils, as shown in Fig. 2 [8].
Fig. 2. Raw materials most used in the production of biodiesel in the world. (Source: Adapted from UFOP,

Table 1 shows the percentage of us e of raw materials for the production of biodiesel in Brazil [9]. Soybean oil is the most used raw material, followed by animal fat. The use of used frying oil is still irrelevant, requiring, therefore, more efforts and studies to become a viable alternati ve in the production process.

Table 1 Percentage of use of raw materials for the production of biodiesel in Brazil. Used frying oil 0% 1% 1% 2% 2% Miscellaneous raw materials 0% 1% 1% 2% 2% Other fatty materials 1% 4% 10% 10% 13% (Source: Adapted from ABIOVE, 2019.)
Depending on the raw material used in the process, the characteristics of biodiesel are modified, changing specification parameters such as pour point, freezing point, iodine index and stability.
The main alcohols used in transesterification are ethanol and methanol, the latter being the most used in the production process.

Several oilseeds are used in the production of biodiesel, including: soybean, palm, canola, sunflower and cotton. In the last 5 years, soybean oil has contributed approximately 70% to the production of biodiesel in Brazil (Table 1).

The soybean can contain 16-20 % of oil, whereas copra (dry coconut pulp) can reach up to 65 - 70 % of oil. The most important oily fruits are olives and palm fruits, which contain 23 -35 % and 40 - 50 % of oil, respectively. Therefore, the oil content will depend on the type of grain or seed analyzed Fats from animal slaughter are an economic attraction for the production of biodiesel, since the large amount of fatty residues produced implies low cost and immediate availability of the raw material in agro -industrial areas. In ad dition, the use of animal fats contributes to the reduction of environmental impacts, avoiding the improper destination of these residues that are not processed and disposed of correctly.

When compared to vegetable oil biodiesel, that obtained from animal fat has advantages such as a higher number of cetane, greater oxidation stability and lower iodine index [11]. Due to the presence of high concentrations of saturated fatty acids, animal fat gives biodiesel a high cloud point and fluidity when compared to that obtained from vegetable oils. These aspects are seen as disadvantages. Another drawback is the fat solidification during the product manufacturing process, a problem that must also be overcome in the plant. Frying oils represent a surprising offer pot ential, exceeding the most optimistic expectations. Such oils originate in certain food production industries, in commercial and institutional restaurants and even in snack bars [7].

The frying process can be defined as heating the oil at temperatures betw een 160 and 220 °C, in the presence of air and water, for long periods of time. During the frying process, some physical and chemical changes occur in the oil [12]:

● Increased viscosity; ● Increased specific heat; ● Decrease in the number of iodine; ● Change in s urface tension; ● Change in appearance (color); ● Increased acidity due to the formation of free fatty acids; ● Unpleasant odor (rancid); ● Increased tendency of oil to foam.

Monitoring the acidity in frying oils is extremely important to verify the viability of using such raw material in the generation of biodiesel. The frying oil needs a pre -treatment, usually filtration steps to remove particulates and decantation to separate the water, mainly from frozen foods, before being used in the reaction.

In principle, any short chain aliphatic alcohol is suitable to be reactive in the transesterification reaction, however the best alcohols are those of low molecular weight (C1 - C4). The smaller the size of the alcohol, the greater the reaction capacity. The reactions tha t use long chain alcohol must be carried out in a higher temperature range or a greater amount of alcohol or catalyst must be used to shift the reaction balance towards the products [7]. The production of biodiesel using ethanol has the following advantage s over production with methanol:
● Low toxicity; ● Renewable raw material; ● Ethyl esters have a higher number of cetane when compared to methyl esters.

However, the most widely used alcohol at the national and international level is methanol, mainly due to the ease and lower cost of recovery and dehydration. Depending on the operational parameters applied, the use of methanol in the transesterification reaction leads to a higher yield of the product associated with a lower consumption of alcohol when compared t o ethanol.
Although the excess of alcohol contributes to the formation of products in transesterification, the excess of ethanol in the reaction is mentioned as a disadvantage to some authors.

Steluti [13], used synthetic samples representing an ideal reac tion medium, composed only of the main products of the transesterification reaction (biodiesel, ethanol and glycerin), verifying that the presence of ethanol increases the solubility of biodiesel in glycerin and vice versa, acting as a co -solvent and thus making the process of separating these substances by decantation difficult.

1.2. Main technological routes for the production of biodiesel
The main technological routes for obtaining biodiesel are: ● alkaline transesterification; ● acid transesterification; ● esterification, ● hydroesterification.

In the transesterification process, a reaction occurs between a triglyceride and an alcohol (usually methyl or ethyl), generating biodiesel and glycerol. This reaction occurs in the presence of a catalyst, whether this acid is basic, enzymatic or heterogeneous. More than 250 biodiesel plants in the world use alkaline transesterification with methanol, since it is the simplest and most economical process for their production. Despite that, this route makes it necessary to remove the catalyst and glycerin during the biodiesel purification stage, requiring additional stages of neutralization, washing and drying at the plant, increasing the final cost of the products and generating an environmental liability because of the ef fluents produced [14].

A process for converting high acid oils is hydroesterification. In this process, the amount of free fatty acids or water present in the fatty material is not relevant, as the first step in the process is the hydrolysis of triacylglyc erols. Then, the glycerol and water are separated from the medium and the fatty acids are subjected to an esterification process, where they are converted into biodiesel and water, which can be reused in the hydrolysis stage. The main advantages of this pr ocess are the possibility of using cheaper raw materials, obtaining a clearer glycerin, thus facilitating its use in other processes, and obtaining a biodiesel free from contamination with acylglycerols.

Esterification consists of obtaining esters from the reaction between a fatty acid and an alcohol (methanol or ethanol), with the formation of water as a by -product. It differs from transesterification, as the raw materials used are fatty acids instead of triglycerides, which makes it more advantageous due to the possibility of using low added value raw materials (such as waste and acidic lees) and the non -formation of glycerol. It differs from the hydroesterification process because it does not require the hydrolysis step, since the raw material is already a fatty acid. The major disadvantage of such a process is the low availability of these acidic wastes for large -scale production [15]. However, in recent times, some plants have used this technological route in the pre -treatment of the raw material in order to reduce acidity for later conversion by transesterification.
1.3. Oxidation processes and chemical stability of oils and esters

Oxidation stability is one of the main quality problems of biodiesel. In recent years, almost 75% of the biodiesel produce d in Brazil came from soybean oil. Due to the high content of unsaturated fatty acids present in this raw material, this biodiesel needs the addition of antioxidant additives. Frying oil, whose major component is soybean oil, also has low oxidative stabili ty, making it necessary to use antioxidants.
Unsaturated fatty acids are present in the composition of soybean oil in more than 80% of the total fatty acids present, as shown in Table 3 [16].

(Source: Adapted from MA & HANNA,

The physical properties of fatty acids and the compounds containing t hem are largely determined by the length and degree of unsaturation of the hydrocarbon chain therein. As a result of the origin of different fatty acid esters, they have different properties. In general, for saturated and unsaturated compounds, we have the following behavior of the properties of the fuels from which they will be derived (Table 4) [17], [18].

Table 4 Variation of fuel properties according to the fatty acid from which they are derived Properties Type of fatty acid Saturated Monoun saturated Polyunsaturated Cetane number High Average Low Freezing point High Average Low Oxidation stability High Average Low NO x emission Reduction Medium increase High increase Lubricity* Low Average High Viscosity* Increases with chain length and saturation Combustion heat Increases with increasing ester chain Cloud and Pour points* Decrease with increasing ester branching (Source: Adapted from TYSON et al., 2004 and * GHADGE and HIFJUR, 2005.)

Although the chemical stability properties of biod iesel have been studied for only 20 years, the chemical stability properties of fatty oils have been the subject of studies for 80 years. The chemical reactivity of the olefinic unsaturation of the fatty acid chain (part of a triglyceride or a monoalkyl es ter, such as methyl ester) can be highly susceptible to oxidative and thermal instability [19], [20].

Esters under conditions of heat, ultraviolet radiation (photo -oxidation), atmospheric air (auto -oxidation), moisture and metals, even for a short period o f time, induce biodiesel to the oxidative process (formation of free radicals, combination with oxygen, formation and cleavage of peroxides in unsaturation, release of aldehydes, carboxylic acids and polymers) The oxidation of biodiesel can lea d to the formation of gums and undesirable polymeric compounds, increased viscosity, increased acidity (capable of generating abiotic corrosive processes) [23] and attack on elastomers by hydroperoxides. Metals, free fatty acids, acid fuel additives, the size of the alcohol group (for mono esters) and the presence of natural antioxidants can impact the oxidation stability of the fatty oil and/or ester. In recent studies, it has been found that 70 ppm of copper in canola oil considerably increases the oxida tion measured by oxygen consumption [24]. In another study comparing the oxidation of oleic (18:1), linoleic (18:2) and linolenic (18:3) acids and their corresponding methyl esters, acids were far more susceptible to oxidation than their respective esters [25]. The trend towards increased stability was linolenic <linoleic <oleic.

The presence of free fatty acids accelerates the oxidation process, since they oxidize more quickly than the corresponding acylglycerols. Furthermore, when present in large quantit ies, they can facilitate the incorporation of traces of metals from equipment or storage tanks [26].
1.4. Antioxidants

Antioxidants are compounds that slow down, control or inhibit substrate self -oxidation processes and decrease the production of unwant ed by -products. There are two types of antioxidants: chain breakers (primary antioxidants) and decomposers of hydroperoxides (secondary antioxidants).

Primary antioxidants ( AH) delay or stop the propagation reaction by donating a hydrogen atom to a free r adical (especially to the peroxyl radical ROO●). Substituted phenolic compounds, secondary aromatic amines, thiophenols and tocopherols are examples of this class [27]. In Fig. 3, a general mechanism for the action of primary antioxidants is presented [28] :

Fig. 3. General mechanism of action for primary antioxidants. AH - antioxidant with an active hydrogen atom; RO ● - alkoxy radical; ROO ● - peroxyl radical and A ● - stable radical. (Source: Adapted from FATTAH et al.,

The antioxidant unstable hydrogen atom (HA) is transferred to the free radicals RO● and ROO● with greater ease when compared to the allylic hydrogens of unsaturated oil molecules. Thus, inactive species are formed for this chain reaction and a free radical (A●) from the antioxida nt. This radical, stabilized by resonance, does not have the ability to initiate or propagate oxidative reactions [29]. The following reactions between RO●, ROO● and A● radicals compete with chain propagation reactions [28].

Secondary antioxidants work by decomposing hydroperoxides or restoring hydrogen into chain -breaking antioxidants or inactivating singlet oxygen, metal ions and pro -oxidative enzymes [27]. Organophosphate and thiosinergist antioxidants are often used as hydroperoxide decomposers to prev ent the formation of highly reactive hydroxy and alkoxy radicals (Fig.4). Organophosphate compounds are normally used in combination with a primary antioxidant [30].
Fig. 4. Decomposition of hydroperoxides due to the action of organophosphate compounds. (Source: Adapted from AMBROGI et al., 2017.)

Crude fatty oils, derived from oil sources, naturally contain antioxidants. The most widely studied is tocopherol. Depending on the refining process used during the manufacture of the oil, tocopherol may or ma y not be contained in the processed oil. In some circumstances, fatty oils may still contain 500 to 1000 ppm of tocopherol after refining. Mendonça [26] compared the antioxidant action of the polyamines spermine and spermidine to those of BHA, BHT, tocophe rol, rosemary and green tea extracts in soybean oil without adding antioxidants using Rancimat at 110 °C. The results showed that the amines were more effective than BHA, BHT, tocopherol and rosemary extract in concentrations of 0.01 to 0.06 g/100 g and mo re effective than green tea extract in concentrations of 0.04 to 0.06 g/100 g, concluding that polyamines are effective antioxidants with potential for use in food, especially in soybean oil.

Maia et al . [31] evaluated the oxidative stability of biodiesel B100, produced from soybean oil, in the presence of pure and mixed synthetic antioxidants BHA, TBHQ and BHT in the simplex -centroid model. The results of the antioxidants, both separately and in mixture, showed an induction period greater than 6 hours at 1 10 °C. It was observed that, depending on the temperature, antioxidants act in different ways, showing greater efficiency for BHA and TBHQ in preventing the oxidation process of biofuel B100.
2. Materials and methods

This topic lists and describes all t he inputs, materials and methods used in the transesterification reaction of the UCO mixture with refined vegetable oil to obtain biodiesel and in the tests with antioxidant agents carried out afterwards. UCO was collected in a restaurant in the south of t he city of Rio de Janeiro.
2.1. Inputs

In the transesterification reaction, the following inputs were used: ● Used cooking oil (reagent): with high water content and acidity, presence of solid residues, strong odor and brown color. ● Refined soybean oil (r eagent). ● Sodium hydroxide micropearls 100% P.A. (catalyst). ● P.A. 99.8% methyl alcohol (reagent). ● Phosphoric acid: used to neutralize transesterification products containing residues of the basic catalyst.

In the biodiesel oxidation tests, the commercial s ynthetic antioxidants BHT and TBHQ were provided by the company Proquímios, and the antioxidants Kerobit TP26 and Kerobit 3627, by the company Basf - The Chemical Company. ● TBHQ: tert -butylhydroquinone (lot: 10001011213) ● BHT: butylhydroxytoluene (batches: 7 8 and 150) ● Kerobit TP 26: 2,6 -Di-tert-butylphenol (lot: 508823) ● Kerobit 3627: 3,6,9 -triazaundecamethylenediamine (lot: 210320)

BHT was selected due to its low toxicity and wide use in the industrial market. The presence of activating groups in the aromati c ring, ortho - and para - substituted, gives its antioxidant action, since it contributes to the better electron relocation and stabilization of free radicals, formed in oxidative processes [32].

Kerobit products, according to the manufacturer BASF, have ph enolic -type compounds and amine -type antioxidants to improve the oxidation stability of mineral oil distillates. These additives are used to prevent hydrocarbon oxidation and the formation of large molecule sediments. Fuel stability is improved and blockin g of filters and jets is avoided for this type of material. Whenever possible, inhibitors are added directly to the plants to ensure the protective effect as quickly as possible.

For the TP26 and 3627 additives in this line, the manufacturer carried out pr eliminary tests with biodiesel and established that its performance depends on the amount of use recommended, which may vary according to the quality of the biodiesel used, concentration of natural antioxidants, concentration of unsaturated, process techni cal and storage conditions. Kerobit 3627 is generally used in the 100 -500 ppm range, both in biodiesel and in oils. The concentrations of Kerobit TP26 used by Basf are in the range of 200 -1000 ppm for biodiesel.

2.2 Pre -treatment of frying oil

A previous treatment of the used oil was carried out so that solid residues and a cer tain amount of water were removed from the raw material. The pretreatment occurred as preparation of the oil for the alkaline transesterification reaction. The following procedure was performed:

a) Determination of the water content present in the collected f rying oil: The water content present in the collected raw frying oil, determined by Karl Fischer equipment, b) Determination of the content of solid residues by centrifugation (bench centrifuge, mo. 206 BL - FANEM) at 2300 rpm for 10 minutes: By means of centrifugation, the content of initial impurities present in the collected frying oil was determined. After 10 minutes of centrifugation at 2300 rpm, the sample separated into 4 phases, with approximately 12 % v/v of solid waste; c) Weigh ing of the sample to be treated (100 g in each aliquot, 4 aliquots processed); d) Heating the samples to 60 ºC and removing the initial water (with decanting funnel): All samples were heated to temperatures between 50 -60 ºC, using an oil bath heated in a heat ing plate and stirring, remaining at this temperature for 15 minutes . After this period, they were placed in a separating funnel to remove the denser phase (water and solid impurities); e) Weighing of the sample followed by an acidity index test: After separ ation, the mass of the less dense fraction was determined. Then, an aliquot was removed from it for the acidity index test. The results are shown in Table 6.

2.3 Characterization of refined oil and treated frying oil

In a stage prior to the alkaline transesterification reaction, there was a physicochemical characterization of the treated frying oil and the refined soybean oil. The lipid profile of the oils was also determined. The methods and procedures adopted in this wo rk followed standards of international standardization.

For the characterization of the oils, tests of aspect, acidity index, water content, iodine index, specific mass and gas chromatography (lipid profile) were performed. Below is a brief description of each test performed:

Aspect: There is no reference table for the classification of the appearance of oils and fats. The appearance of the raw material was assessed qualitatively based on the description of the visual aspect of the sample. A good quality o il must be clear, homogeneous and free from impurities and solid residues.

Acidity Index: The acidity of an oil or fat, as well as the rancification states, is a highly variable characteristic that depends on the state or condition of the lipids. The acidi ty index was determined according to the AOCS (American Oil Chemists' Society) Cd 3d -63 standard. Water content: The water content was obtained by titration according to the Karl Fischer method (Schott, model Tritoline KF), in order to verify the oil condi tion for the reactions to obtain biodiesel. This analysis was determined according to the official ASTM D - 6304 method.

Iodine index: It is a measure of the degree of unsaturation (double bonds) of an oil or fat and it is expressed in terms of the number of grams of iodine absorbed per gram of the sample. The iodine index was determined following the AOCS Cd 1 -25 standard, using Wijs reagent.

Desnsity at 20 °C: Specific gravity is the mass per unit volume at a specified temperature. The specific mass was det ermined according to the ASTM D4052 standard. Lipid profile: Gas chromatography is the most used technique in the analysis of the fatty acid profile present in lipids. As a limitation of the evaluation technique, it is necessary to convert fatty acids into more volatile substances in order to reduce the adsorption of solutes on the support and surface of the column and improve the separation of compounds. Methyl esters are the derivatives preferably used in gas chromatography.

In the first stage, the methyl ated compounds were generated and then separated to be evaluated in gas chromatography. 300 mg of oil underwent a saponification by reacting with 2 ml of saturated solution of potassium hydroxide (0.5 mol/L) in methanol followed by an esterification with 2 ml of a solution of methanol with 5 % hydrochloric acid. Both reactions occurred in a closed environment at 75 °C for 10 minutes in a water bath. 2 ml of distilled water and 2 ml of hexane P.A. were added to separate the methylated fatty acid compounds of interest from the others. The organic phase with hexane was then sent to the second stage. In the second stage, the fatty acid methyl esters of the oil were analyzed in a gas chromatograph of the type GC2014 Shimadzu, coupled to a flame ionization detecto r, split / splitless injector and a capillary column called Carbowax 20M. Stationary phase polyethylene glycol 30 cm long, 0.25 mm internal diameter and 0.25 µm film thickness. The operational parameters are listed in Table 8.

2.4 Procedure used in alkaline transesterification reactions

Before starting the alkaline transesterification reactions, several samples using different mass percentages of refined oil and used oil were weighed. After mixing the oils, the acidity and humidity of the samples were determined.

Biodiesel was produced by alkaline transesterification weighing approximat ely 90g of each mixture, using methanol as a reagent and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) as the reaction catalyst. Methanol was fixed at 30% in relation to the heavy quantity of the oil samples. There was a variation in the amount of catalyst for some mixtures in order to verify the reaction yield behavior.
The reaction system was kept under stirring for 60 minutes at 40ºC (Fig. 5).
Fig. 5. Reaction system used in transesterification reactions

After the reaction, the glycerin -rich phase was separated by decanta tion and the biodiesel -rich phase was subjected to two washing steps with distilled water at a temperature In the first washing step, a hot water solution with 0.05% by volume of phosphoric acid was used to neutralize the catalyst and remove unrea cted alcohol. Finally, in the drying stage, the biodiesel was heated to 105 ºC to remove the water and, subsequently, anhydrous sodium sulfate was added to reach the humidity parameter established by the ANP.
The biodiesel produced under the different cond itions was preliminarily characterized. From this characterization, mixtures that met the specification of RANP nº45 of 25/08/2014 were selected [33].
2.5 Characterization of biodiesel

The methods for characterizing the biodiesel generated in this work f ollowed those contained in the specification of RANP nº45 of 25/08/2014. Tests of color, acidity, humidity, oxidative stability and contents of esters, monoglycerides, diglycerides, triglycerides, free and total glycerol were performed.
2.6 Procedure app lied in tests with antioxidants in biodiesel

In the biodiesel produced from the mixture of 80% refined oil with 20% used oil, 3 concentrations (630, 757 and 884 ppm) of 5 different antioxidants were tested (TBHQ, BHT lot 78, BHT lot 150, Kerobit TP 46 and Kerobit 3627). The concentrations were selected based on recommendations from BASF itself, which supplies Kerobit additives. Fifteen samples were evaluated, using approximately 3 g of each one in the oxidative stability test (Rancimat equipment).

Rancimat oxidation stability analysis: The analysis consisted of exposing 3 g of sample (oil or ester) in a test tube to a stream of purified air (10 L / h) at a temperature of 110 ° C. The steam released during the oxidation process (low molecular weight organic acids), along with air , passed through a flask containing water (demineralized or distilled) and an electrode to monitor the conductivity of this solution. The electrode was connected to a measuring and recording device (computer). Method 14112: 2003 was fo llowed.

The acidity index must be less than 2.0 mg KOH / g for transesterification to be considered efficient (ALBUQUERQUE, 2006). As previously men tioned, the maximum water content allowed is 2% for the evaluated scenario. Therefore, the results obtained from humidity and acidity index were satisfactory, noting that sample 6 presented an acidity index at the maximum limit pre -established by the liter ature.

Following the procedure used for the alkaline transesterification reaction, fixing in this step the amount of the NaOH catalyst to 1% of the total mass of oil, batches of crude biodiesel were produced. All sa mples failed, according to RNAP 45/2014, for the oxidative stability test, indicating the need to use antioxidant agents. Failure of the test is related to the lipid profile of vegetable oils, which are predominantly unsaturated (Figures 6 and 7). The wate r content in all samples was above the established limit of 200 ppm. Even after heating and adding adsorbent, a relatively high final water content was obtained. It was not possible to perform heating at atmospheric pressure for a long time to avoid degrad ation of the samples. However, this fact can be easily circumvented in the plants, using vacuum in the drying step. The other results obtained for samples 1, 2 and 3 (0 %, 10 % and 20 % of oil used in the composition of the mixture, respectively) were with in the biodiesel specification range. Sample 4 (25 % of oil used in the mixture) indicated results at the specification limit for the other parameters, while the results of samples 5 and 6 (30 % and 40 % of frying oil, respectively) did not meet the specif ication.

As the percentage of frying oil increases in the mixture, the acidity index increases and the ester content decreases for the final product generated. The increase in moisture in the raw material can cause the generation of free fatty acids, causi ng undesirable saponification reactions and, consequently, reducing the reaction yield.

For mixtures containing 25% cooking oil, increasing the catalyst from 1% to 1.20% was beneficial for the reaction, resulting in a higher yield of ester content and a lower acidity index (samples 4 and 7). The increase from 1.20% to 1.5%, brought a slightly lower yield (samples 7 and 10).

The behavior with the increase in the amount of catalyst in the reaction is the same for mixtures with 40% of frying oil. At first, the increase is beneficial for the reaction, bringing a higher yield of the final product and a lower acidity index (samples 6 and 9), but then with the increase there is a decrease in the percentage of ester generated (samples 9 and 12) . Even with the increase in catalyst in the reaction medium for samples 9 and 12, the ester content in the final product produced does not meet the specifications of RNAP 45/2014. The increase in the catalyst in the medium can lead us to higher yields or, even, to reaction mechanisms for the formation of other products, reducing the quantity of the desired final product. Saponification reactions may have occurred in the increase from 1.20% to 1.5% NaOH in the reactions.

The antioxidant agents used in this study were tested in different concentrations and added to the biodiesel obtained from the mixture 80% of refined oil with 20% of used oil, as described in item 2.6. After performing the oxidative stability test, the results showed in Table 15 were obtained:

(Source: Author, 2020.) TBHQ indicated satisfactory results at concentrations of 757 ppm and 884 ppm. Kerobit 3627 showed satisf actory results in the three concentrations prepared for the study. However, the increase in stability of the samples added with BHT and Kerobit TP26 in the studied concentrations was not enough to overcome the limit established in the biodiesel quality spe cification, which was changed in 2019 to 12 h. The amine -based antioxidant (Kerobit 3627) performed better when compared to phenolic -type antioxidants (Kerobit TP26, BHT and TBHQ). TBHQ was more efficient when compared to BHT and Kerobit TP26, indicating t hat the interaction between such additive and the free radicals formed was more stable, providing a longer oxidation resistance time for the The frying oil present in the biodiesel raw material contributes to greater amounts of antioxidants being adde d in order to increase oxidative stability. The presence of free fatty acids in higher content and the reduction of oxidation stability due to the frying time, are negative factors for the quality of the final biodiesel in terms of the evaluated aspect.
4. Conclusions

Preliminary laboratory tests indicated the possibility of producing specified biodiesel from a mixture of refined soybean oil and frying oil used in mass proportions of 80% and 20%, respectively, without the need for a treatment to reduce ac idity frying oil. The increase of the catalyst from 1% to 1.20% on the total mass of oil was beneficial for the reactions, allowing the use of a higher percentage of frying oil in the mixtures, producing biodiesel within the specified parameters. The resul ts of the samples with the increase of the catalyst to 1.5% were not satisfactory, they showed an acidity index and an out of specification ester content, indicating the occurrence of parallel reactions in the medium. For all the characterized samples, the oxidative stability test failed, as expected due to the high degree of unsaturation present in the evaluated raw materials.

The oxidative stability tests carried out on the 80:20 mixture (refined oil:UCO) using the evaluated antioxidants (TBHQ, BHT, Kerob it TP26 and Kerobit 3627), in 3 different concentrations, showed that all results with Kerobit 3627 were satisfactory, being the antioxidant of higher performance in the tests. The results for TBHQ at concentrations of 757 and 884 ppm met the established l imits. The other antioxidants produced results out of specification in the concentrations analyzed at work.

Fantinel [34] and Dantas [35] presented works in which biodiesel is produced using only UCO as raw material, making it difficult to specify the fina l product. The mixture of UCO with refined vegetable oil would be one of the alternatives to eliminate this problem, providing biodiesel production with the necessary quality for use, without the need to modify existing technologies in the plants.
